conclusion: Circular light hole in a horizontal roof with thickness d = 20√3 cm and diameter L = 40 cm.
Glass brick with refractive index n = √3 is embedded in the hole.
Determine how much the range of incident light angles increases after embedding the glass brick.
Maximum angle of incidence without the glass brick is calculated using tan(θ) = L/2 / d = 1/√3, resulting in θ = 30°.
Using Snell's law, the maximum incident angle with the glass brick is calculated as φ = arcsin(√3/2) = 60°.
Increase in angular range is calculated as 60° - 30° = 30°.
Second diagram shows original maximum angle of 30° and new maximum angle of 60°.
The range of light incident on the central point at the bottom of the light-transmitting hole is increased by 30 degrees.
